dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, productivity growth has just totally tanked everywhere globally, right? It's just flatlined.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, productivity growth has just totally tanked everywhere globally, right? It's just flatlined.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the two decades since 2004, US productivity growth, as measured by the value of output per hour worked, has been more than double that of the eurozone. Whereas eurozone productivity has flat-lined and even fallen slightly since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, US non-farm output per hour has risen by more than 6% over the same period

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No! Oh my god, no! That's, um, actually completely wrong, Host_A. The US, like, its productivity growth has more than doubled Europe's since 2004.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No! Oh my god, no! That's, um, actually completely wrong, Host_A. The U S, like, its productivity growth has more than doubled Europe's since two thousand four.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the two decades since 2004, US productivity growth, as measured by the value of output per hour worked, has been more than double that of the eurozone.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! I mean, that's wild. Especially, like, post-COVID. Europe's totally flat, even down, and the US? Up 6%?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! I mean, that's wild. Especially, like, post-COVID. Europe's totally flat, even down, and the U S? Up six percent?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Whereas eurozone productivity has flat-lined and even fallen slightly since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, US non-farm output per hour has risen by more than 6% over the same period

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh, exactly! And people are all, "Oh, it's just the US fiscal stimulus," you know? All that government spending.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh, exactly! And people are all, Oh, it's just the U S fiscal stimulus, you know? All that government spending.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some accounts point to the strong fiscal stimulus applied in the US since the outbreak of the pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right! Like, "It's transitory, they can't keep spending forever." But, um, that doesn't really explain productivity, does it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! Like, It's transitory, they can't keep spending forever. But, um, that doesn't really explain productivity, does it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For Europeans this explanation is reassuring, because it suggests that the differential is transitory. ... But while strong spending stimulus can trigger rapid output and employment growth, it is not clear why it should produce faster productivity growth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, exactly! If anything, you'd think tight labor markets would mean hiring less productive people, right? But it's actually making companies replace people.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, exactly! If anything, you'd think tight labor markets would mean hiring less productive people, right? But it's actually making companies replace people.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On the contrary, given strong employment growth and tight labor markets, one might expect US companies to be forced to take on less productive workers, with negative implications for output per hour. More likely, tight labor markets in the US may mean that firms, unable to find an adequate supply of workers at any price, are impelled to substitute capital for labor to invest in labor-saving technology.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! Like, uh, ATMs everywhere, QR codes for ordering even at fancy restaurants. No human tellers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! Like, uh, ATMs everywhere, Q R codes for ordering even at fancy restaurants. No human tellers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Americans visiting a bank branch will encounter plenty of ATMs but sometimes not a single human teller. They are compelled to order meals, even at white-tablecloth restaurants, using a QR code.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Mmm-hmm, capital for labor, baby! But wait, it's not just post-COVID, though. The US was already outperforming pre-pandemic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mmm-hmm, capital for labor, baby! But wait, it's not just post-COVID, though. The U S was already outperforming pre-pandemic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Recall, however, that US productivity growth had accelerated relative to Europes already in the decade leading up to the pandemic, when labor markets were not so tight.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, exactly! Even before labor markets got this tight. Like, after the 2008 crisis, both went through austerity, but Europe was like, more hell-bent on it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, exactly! Even before labor markets got this tight. Like, after the two thousand eight crisis, both went through austerity, but Europe was like, more hell-bent on it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Both the US and Europe turned to fiscal consolidation following the 2008 global financial crisis. Europe might have been slightly more hell-bent on austerity, but there was not enough difference in demand conditions to explain their different productivity outcomes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And the digital tech thing? Like, American firms were faster with it, but that was mostly before 2008. The timing's off now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And the digital tech thing? Like, American firms were faster with it, but that was mostly before two thousand eight. The timing's off now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, while American firms have been quicker to capitalize on digital technologies, the timing is wrong here, too: US outperformance in computer producing and using sectors was most pronounced in the decade preceding the global financial crisis, not in the period since.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! And AI? LLMs? People are saying that's it, but that's just starting, you know? The J-curve, where it falls before it rises?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! And A I? LLMs? People are saying that's it, but that's just starting, you know? The J-curve, where it falls before it rises?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As for the latest round of new digital technologies, firms are only just now beginning to explore how large language models and generative artificial intelligence can be used to boost productivity. ... The inevitability of errors means that productivity is likely to fall before rising, a phenomenon economists call the productivity J-curve.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh, that takes time. So then, like, what's wrong with Europe? Is it, um, the unions? Or those strict EU rules?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh, that takes time. So then, like, what's wrong with Europe? Is it, um, the unions? Or those strict E U rules?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It could be that Europes strong trade unions, fearing job destruction, resist their adoption... Alternatively, restrictive European Union rules may be impeding adoption.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! Data privacy, the AI rulebook, all that stuff. And then, Putin, you know? Energy shock.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! Data privacy, the A I rulebook, all that stuff. And then, Putin, you know? Energy shock.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The EUs data-privacy regulations, and now its proposed AI rulebook, if adhered to strictly, may slow the development of AI applications. Finally, it could simply be that Europe has had bad luck, specifically in the form of Russian President Vladimir Putin and his energy-price shock.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh my god, yes, exactly! That's been brutal for them. The US being energy self-sufficient, huge advantage.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh my god, yes, exactly! That's been brutal for them. The U S being energy self-sufficient, huge advantage.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The US, being self-sufficient in energy, has not been vulnerable to energy-supply disruptions to the same degree.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But Draghi, like, he's got proposals coming, right? All these old ideas for productivity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But Draghi, like, he's got proposals coming, right? All these old ideas for productivity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Mario Draghi, Europes senior economic statesman, will present the EU with a set of proposals later this year for boosting productivity. ... Observers like me can confidently predict what Draghi will recommend because such proposals have been around for years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! Capital markets union, competition, energy self-sufficiency, supply chains. Like, stuff they've known for ages.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! Capital markets union, competition, energy self-sufficiency, supply chains. Like, stuff they've known for ages.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: No doubt, he will recommend completing Europes capital-markets union so that firms can more easily finance investments in new technologies. Draghi will recommend removing barriers to competition... He will advocate greater energy efficiency and self-sufficiency to free Europe from more Putin-like disruptions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And, um, they just need to actually do them, like, now! And maybe invent some new ones too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, um, they just need to actually do them, like, now! And maybe invent some new ones too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Europe should move now to implement these old ideas. And it desperately needs to come up with new ones.
